12. 
omissions in the observations or records". 
He adds " the failure arises from the fact that 
the Explorers brough back no certain information about 
the amount of slope of the barrier surface towards the 
sea". 
There is no direct charge of default in these 
remarks but together with their Context they plainly 
suggest that something was left undone which might have been done. 
In this matter I am personally concerned as 
I conducted the journey to the South and was keenly 
alive to the desirability of ascertaining the changes of 
level and therefrom the barometric gradient. 
I have explained the problem and noted the 
difficulty in the narrative of the Voyage (Pages 418, 419). 
It was impossible to tell whether the differ-
ences of pressure at our stations and at the Ship were 
due to a barometric gradient or to inequalities of level 
since there was no method by which the latter could be 
measured. 
It is therefore obvious that in this respect 
nothing was left undone and the <s>"\s>second "crucial test" is 
one which could not have been satisfied by any known means. 
Under these circumstances it seems unnecessary 
to have mentioned such a test, and as mentioned it is 
unjust to note the 'omissions of observations' without 
<u>explaining<\u>
